para.caption: Installing XP for multiple projects
para.text:
Foreword: please note that these instructions aim to CVS as the version control system and may not apply in it's whole to the current system which is subversion. We leave these instructions online as they still contain true and useful information for CVS users.
Developers that take strong use of xp often need to install XP on various machines and for various projects.
While one develops an application XP at the same time may grow and develop; especially after the development of the application XP still grows and may do some API changes.
Though it's the policy of the xp core developer team that a stable class or collection should not perform an API change but should be changed backward compatible, there have already been occasions (and probably there will be some more) where a API change disturbing compatibility may be neccessary.
We have created a plan how the framework can be installed on a machine multiple times, with certain versioning information, so that it is possible to always keep an working version that still fits your application installed, but letting open the possibility to follow an API change and update various parts of XP.

para.caption: How versioning works in XP
para.text:
The complete XP framework is managed via CVS. CVS allows for unlimited undo-operations, diffing of versions, conflict resolution, branching, merging and many more.
Branching and merging may be useful for applications where you often need to create working code while continue changing various parts of the code. With this method you can quite comfortably create snapshots containing newest features and also stable, old code (that could have been changed in another branch). We feel that creating branches is quite unlikely for a framework, and thus have decided to do without branching.
We follow the simple rules of tagging a specific version at e.g. release-time of an application.
One may install only versions of files containing a certain tag, that is only used for this application.
That way one freezes the framework but can easily jump on new versions if desired.

para.caption: So how to install?
para.text:
Once you've finished your development, find all classes that your application needs from XP, find a suitable name for your tag (recommended is a small prefix that is somehow related to your application (e.g. the initials) plus the word RELEASE). In our example we use the tag APP_RELEASE.
Now tag all classes from the framework, that you need, including all dependency classes. Now, go to your target machine, preferably as root (as noone else should be able to create directories at /usr/local/lib/) and do:
cd /usr/local/lib mkdir xp.app-release && cd xp.app-release cvs -d:ext:alex@php3.de:/home/cvs/repositories/xp co -r APP_RELEASE skeleton mv xp/* . rmdir xp chown cgi:users *
I used my user-id alex@php3.de, choose yours. Note, that for this special way of checking out the versions from cvs, the environment must contain CVS_RSH=ssh and you should have agent forwarding turned on for conveniance.
Also note, that this approach has one special requirement: as we cannot allow everyone to tag our classes, you must have a private cvs repository with regularly is merged from the public XP. There exists a script which partially automates the process of merging changes in the public repository into a private one. As we do not know of any other existing private repositories, we have not yet released this script - if you need it, please send a mail to our mailinglist.

para.caption: Then, how to update?
para.text:
Updating from then on is a really simple process. As every class has been checked out from cvs and has not been locally changed (you should never do that), cvs is able to automatically update the files to a new revision - if the tag for your application has been moved.
It's as simple as:
cd /usr/local/lib/xp.app-release/skeleton cvs update -r APP_RELEASE -dP
After the command completes, you have updated every class that has been tagged at a new revision.

para.caption: Moving the tag to a newer version
para.text:
Moving the tag to a newer version may not be a simple task. Tags make sure that the correct revisions of files are checked out for a given project. After moving the tag to another revision involved classes may stop working together and subsequent tag movements may be required.
As tags do not contain information about which version of a file works with another version, it is the duty of the programmer to check if the involved classes still work.
The most simple and sensible way of moving the tags is to move the tags to the HEAD-revision of one or all files. When updateing to HEAD it is most likely that the versions interact correctly. On the other hand HEAD may have introduced (still undetected) bugs, so this is the backdraw. The safest way is to create a stage where you can test all your changes before you install it on your real server.

para.caption: Reverting changes
para.text:
Reverting changes should always result in a new revision (that is a new commit). One should never move a tag backwards to an older revision because other developers will always work on the HEAD version of a file, making changes to HEAD and commit these changes. Then, if they have finished the changes, they will tag the new version of the file and thus, implicitly and not wanted, revert the previous reversion.
So, if you need to revert a change use the -j flag for cvs update.
